awd_titl_txt: CC*DNI Networking Infrastructure: Texas Woman's University Science Research Network
awd_abstract_narration:
Texas Woman's University (TWU) is committed to establishing a dedicated science research network (SRN) for faculty and student researchers, with access to worldwide resources to enrich scientific discovery.  In conjunction with TWU's intensive focus on funded, research-active faculty in the sciences, health sciences and technical areas, the SRN is essential to meeting the data-intensive requirements for a growing number of disciplines.  Key academic programs include, but are not limited to, physical therapy, nursing telehealth, informatics, computer science, biology, chemistry and nutrition. 

TWU's plan is to construct and support a 10 Gbps SRN for researchers to effectively use and share large data sets. The SRN plan has 10 Gbps connectivity to TWU's regional area network, "Lonestar Education and Research Network",  providing TWU researchers access to Internet2.  Such capability is necessary for many faculty and students needing significantly more bandwidth.  For example, TWU's recent development of an informatics program touches multiple disciplines, particularly in health informatics where study questions include hospital reaction time, improved patient care, viral preparedness, and health care outcome modeling.

Additionally, this project provides enhanced research and educational opportunities to a diverse TWU student body, consisting of 87% women, 19% African American and greater than 25% Latino - TWU is designated as a Hispanic-serving institution.  Thus, this project unquestionably furthers TWU's efforts to engage women and minorities in important research opportunities across critical STEM and health care fields.  Recognition of underrepresentation of women and minorities in technical arenas is longstanding.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
As specified in the original submission, Texas Woman's University's (TWU) plan was to construct and support a Science Research Network (SRN) for researchers to effectively use and share large data with 10 Gbps of network connectivity on campus, as well as 10 Gbps connectivity through the Lonestar Education and Research Network (LEARN) to both Texas institutions and Internet2 institutions. The plan included two phases with concrete objectives: (1) Build an edge network to allow large data sets to be transferred to and from other institutions via the Texas LEARN network, via the Internet, and via Internet2 and (2) Create an internal Science Research Network allowing large data streams to be moved and utilized on campus.

Staff from the Office of Technology at TWU successfully completed both objectives of the proposed project that build the physical SRN. Figure 1 illustrates the physical SRN pre- and post-implementation. Figure 2 illustrates the data-driven network after the grant-funded upgrade.

In addition to the work done as part of the NSF grant, TWU upgraded their other WAN connection, making bandwidth available for University research traffic.

TWU has an emerging culture of faculty and students creating scholarship by leveraging powerful data, software, and hardware resources, aligned with the University's strategic plan. Following implementation of the network, the scholarly goals set forth in TWU's grant application have been met and new opportunities have emerged.

In a commitment to expanding its research profile and supporting new degrees, TWU has hired new faculty whose research is dependent upon access to big data sets and the use of complex algorithms. The SRN makes this research possible for faculty and their students.

TWU has new informatics and health informatics degrees, which require access to high-speed bandwidth. These new degrees provide TWU's graduates with unlimited opportunities in the developing market of informatics. Further, the TWU School of Library and Information Studies has developed a specialization in "Community Informatics" to prepare students to use data and Information and Communication Technology within community-based organizations (including libraries) for the benefit of local communities.

Additionally, student and faculty research is conducted in a newly created Informatics & Virtual Reality lab that utilizes the 40 Gbps connection to enable high-end workstations and displays plus virtual reality systems and sophisticated analysis and modeling software. Another example of research benefitting from the grant-funded network is the use of electron, light, and confocal microscopes that capture images in biology labs.  The new network hardware allows for faster transfer of images.

As a state institution, it is incumbent upon TWU to share knowledge and provide opportunities for communities to interact with and benefit from its many resources. The SRN provides TWU faculty and staff the ability to offer high-tech activities that engage young minds.

Each summer, students entering grades 9-12 participate in TWU & Air Force Association's (AFA) CyberCamp, which emphasizes hands-on learning of cybersecurity principles that are relevant and applicable to everyday life. Developed by the AFA, the camp curriculum covers new topics and engages participants in hands-on activities each day, building to a final team competition simulating real cybersecurity situations faced by industry professionals. The CyberCamp benefits from the SRN because many of the daily activities are hosted at sites across the United States.

The SRN provides the reliable, high-speed connectivity needed for TWU to benefit from its new membership of the Texas Digital Library. Membership supports research, teaching, and digital curation efforts on campus by facilitating collaboration among TWU and external partners and by connecting TWU to a global ecosystem of digital library efforts.


Last Modified: 03/21/2018
Modified by: Andrew Clemens
